org.oucs.oxpoints.entities
Class OxPointsEntity

java.lang.Object
  org.oucs.oxpoints.entities.OxPointsEntity
All Implemented Interfaces:
RDFContainer
Direct Known Subclasses:
OxpEntity
public abstract class OxPointsEntity
extends java.lang.Object
implements RDFContainer

Every defined class in the OxPoints ontology needs a representation in java (a subclass of OxPointsEntity).

About OxPointsEntities

OxPointEntities represent a defined class from the OxPoints ontology at a given point in time. That is, it contains all the attribute values that this object had at a specified time. A representation of an OxPoints object throughout its lifespan can be generated using the OxPointsTimeBasedEntity class.

These entity classes are used by the OxPoints system as an intermediate format to provide an easy to use API when working with the OxPoints library. Since adding new classes to the OxPoints ontology might happen frequently, the actual representation of its java equivalent (the OxPointsEntity) is a very simple JavaBean (see Wikipedia entry), that only contains get and set methods for its attributes. The generation of an entity object from RDF or the creation of RDF from an entity object is entirely handled by the OxPoints system using Java's reflection API. In order to be able to achieve this a set of annotations has been defined that have to be used to mark up the various get and set methods.

For implementation details on how this dynamic loading of entities and their serialization to RDF is done have a look at the methods loadFromSnapshot(Resource, OxPointsSnapshot, OxPointsEntityPool), getTriplesFor().

Creating new OxPointsEntities

Adding new entities to the OxPoints system is easy and we want to show the usual procedure by adding a fictional entity: Computer Monitors.

The first step when adding a new entity to the system is to adjust OxPoints' ontology and add the corresponding owl:class. In this case we could add the following: <owl:Class rdf:ID="ComputerMonitor"/> Next we should rebuild the OxPointsVocab helper class by running the provided ant script (build.xml target: schemas).

Now we can start writing the new OxPointsEntity. We therefor create a new class with the same name as our ontology class and make it a subclass of OxPointsEntity. We have to override the getType method to return the correct ontology class. The basic scheleton would look like this: 

 public class ComputerMonitor extends OxPointsEntity {
           @Override
     public String getType(){
                   return OxPointsVocab.ComputerMonitor_URI;
           }
 }

Next we have to create a field for each bit of information that we want to store. Let's say we want to store a name, the size and the monitors place. We simply add these to our class and create a get and set method for each of them: 

 public class ComputerMonitor extends OxPointsEntity {
           
     private String name;
     private int size;
     private Place place;
        
     @Override      
     public String getType(){
                   return OxPointsVocab.ComputerMonitor_URI;
           }
     
     public void setName(String name){
         this.name = name;
     }
     public String getName(){
         return this.name;
     }
     
     public void setSize(int size){
         this.size = size;
     }
     public int getSize(){
         return this.size;
     }
     
     public void setPlace(Place place){
         this.place = place;
     }
     public Place getPlace(){
         return this.place;
     }
 }

As a last step we have to give OxPoints some clues as to what the methods should be used for. This is done using predefined Annotations.

Adding annotations to guide the dynamic generation/serialization

In order to automatically create RDF from entities or load entities from RDF OxPoints relies upon clues in form of predefined annotations (we call them PropertyAnnotation). All PropertyAnnotations are defined in the package org.oucs.oxpoints.entities.utils. For our ComputerMonitor example we need the two annotations SimpleLiteralProperty and SimpleURIProperty. These tell OxPoints that the marked up method return/store either a literal (SimpleLiteralProperty) or an OxPointsEntity (SimpleURIProperty).

Additionally all PropertyAnnotations get the RDF Property the information corresponds to as a parameter. 

 public class ComputerMonitor extends OxPointsEntity {
           
     private String name;
     private int size;
     private Place place;
        
     @Override
     public String getType(){
                   return OxPointsVocab.ComputerMonitor_URI;
           }
     
     @SimpleLiteralProperty(DC.title)
     public void setName(String name){
         this.name = name;
     }
     @SimpleLiteralProperty(DC.title)
     public String getName(){
         return this.name;
     }
     
     @SimpleLiteralProperty(SomeVocab.hasSize)
     public void setSize(int size){
         this.size = size;
     }
     @SimpleLiteralProperty(SomeVocab.hasSize)
     public int getSize(){
         return this.size;
     }
     
     @SimpleURIProperty(OxPointsVocab.hasParent)
     public void setPlace(Place place){
         this.place = place;
     }
     @SimpleURIProperty(OxPointsVocab.hasParent)
     public Place getPlace(){
         return this.place;
     }
 }

Adding annotations to guide the transformation to various output formats

The transformation of OxPointsEntitys is also guided through annotations (TransformationAnnotation). There are two TransformationAnnotaions: TransformationProperty and TransformationIndirectProperty. The TransformationProperty annotation tells the transformer that the annotated method returns the object it is looking for for the supplied RDF Property. The TransformationIndirectProperty annotation on the other hand tells the transformer that the method's return value is an OxPointsEntity and that it should look for the object it is looking for (defined by the RDF property) there.

In this case we want to mark up the getName method with TransformationProperty and for the monitor's location we tell the transformer to look at the Place object using the TransformationIndirectProperty annotation. 

 public class ComputerMonitor extends OxPointsEntity {
           
     private String name;
     private int size;
     private Place place;
        
     @Override
     public String getType(){
                   return OxPointsVocab.ComputerMonitor_URI;
           }
     
     
     @SimpleLiteralProperty(DC.title)
     public void setName(String name){
         this.name = name;
     }
     @TransformationProperty(DC.title)
     @SimpleLiteralProperty(DC.title)
     public String getName(){
         return this.name;
     }
     
     @SimpleLiteralProperty(SomeVocab.hasSize)
     public void setSize(int size){
         this.size = size;
     }
     @SimpleLiteralProperty(SomeVocab.hasSize)
     public int getSize(){
         return this.size;
     }
     
     @SimpleURIProperty(OxPointsVocab.hasParent)
     public void setPlace(Place place){
         this.place = place;
     }
     @TransformationIndirectProperty(OxPointsVocab.hasLocation)
     @SimpleURIProperty(OxPointsVocab.hasParent)
     public Place getPlace(){
         return this.place;
     }
 }

Constructor Detail

OxPointsEntity

public OxPointsEntity()
Instantiate the OxPointsEntity.

OxPointsEntities should always use the default constructor and provide methods for all their fields in order for OxPoints to be able to automatically load and serialize them.

setTimeSpan

public final void setTimeSpan(TimeSpan ts)
Stores the lifespan of this OxPointsEntity.

The lifespan does not necessary correspond to when the entity came into being and was destroyed. It is the span in which the entity is valid in the form at it is represented by this object.

Parameters:
ts - The lifespan
